assumptions.text: AI agents (Claude Code, Cursor, Code-puppy, etc.) will respect bootstrap files like CLAUDE.md and .cursorrules
File-based artifacts are more durable than agent memory for long-running projects
ELCS can be implemented progressively (Level 0 → Level 4) without breaking earlier levels
Unique terminology (WorkToken, CognitiveCone, etc.) will prevent confusion with other methodologies
The EAR methodology (used to build ELCS) is sufficient to complete this project

hypotheses.claim: Multi-entry bootstrap (CLAUDE.md + .cursorrules + .windsurfrules) will work across 3+ agent environments
hypotheses.falsification: If any major agent environment ignores all bootstrap files, this hypothesis is falsified

hypotheses.claim: ELCS protocol can be followed by agents without custom tooling (pure file-based)
hypotheses.falsification: If agents require custom tools/APIs to follow ELCS, this hypothesis is falsified

hypotheses.claim: WorkToken-based coordination will enable emergent multi-agent collaboration
hypotheses.falsification: If token claiming leads to deadlocks or no coordination improvement, this hypothesis is falsified

hypotheses.claim: Validator agents (Stage B) can enforce quality gates without blocking legitimate work
hypotheses.falsification: If validators cause deadlocks or excessive rejection rates (>30%), this hypothesis is falsified

hypotheses.claim: Coalition contracts (Stage C) enable tighter agent coupling without conflict
hypotheses.falsification: If coalitions produce more conflicts than solo agents, or exit conditions fail to trigger, this hypothesis is falsified

hypotheses.claim: Distance vectors (Stage D) enable self-selection without central dispatcher
hypotheses.falsification: If agents cannot meaningfully compute/use distance vectors, or coordination degrades without dispatcher, this hypothesis is falsified
hypotheses.notes: Needs complex scenario with ambiguous priorities to fully validate

hypotheses.claim: Agents naturally scale rigor to risk without explicit instruction
hypotheses.falsification: If agents apply same ceremony to trivial and complex tasks, this hypothesis is falsified

evidence.summary: Code-puppy and Claude Code both read claude.md/CLAUDE.md files at session start
EAR template (epistemic-agentic-runtime-main) successfully persists state across sessions via files
EAR 12-stage pipeline has guided this project from idea through scaffolding successfully
test-elcs-codepuppy project: Agent followed ELCS protocol (tokens, claims, checkpoints) using only file-based artifacts, no custom tooling
test-elcs-codepuppy project: Bernard delegated WT-008 (web server) to python-programmer sub-agent while implementing 3 other tokens in parallel. No conflicts, proper attribution in claimed_by field.

Agent created single token for simple work (Stage 1), but voluntarily created 4 parallel tokens + sub-agent delegation for complex multi-feature request (Stage 2). Scaled rigor without explicit instruction.

Same ELCS project (test-elcs-codepuppy) successfully read by Code-puppy (AGENTS.md), Claude Code CLI (CLAUDE.md), and VS Code Claude chat mode (CLAUDE.md). All three understood project state, tokens, and checkpoints.

After adding HARD RULES section to CLAUDE.md/AGENTS.md with visual checklist, agent followed full token lifecycle for WT-012: created token BEFORE work, ran pre-edit checklist, ran compliance checklist, wrote checkpoint. Key insight: prominent rules get followed, buried rules get skipped.

Coalition CC-001-web-calculator coordinated 6 agents (planning-agent, python-programmer, code-puppy, qa-kitten, python-reviewer, javascript-reviewer) across 4 tokens with 6 explicit handoffs. Validators had blocking power. Scope boundaries respected. Coalition dissolved cleanly. Delivered: Flask backend, HTML/JS frontend, 41 unit tests, 14 E2E tests.
Agent discovered distance vector protocol in PROTOCOL.md but determined it wasn't needed for simple prioritization with obvious severity differences
Agent successfully self-selected using intuition: security (CRITICAL) → test (HIGH) → docs (MEDIUM). Formal distance vectors unnecessary for obvious priorities.
Protocol First HARD RULE added to bootstrap files. Agent read protocol when prompted but satisficed with simpler approach when priorities were clear.

hard.text: ELCS must work with any agent that can read/write files
hard.rationale: Tool-agnostic is a core design goal

hard.text: All ELCS artifacts must be human-readable (no binary formats)
Template must not require installation or dependencies to use

soft.text: Prefer JSON for structured data, Markdown for prose

soft.rationale: Agents more likely to read short files completely

preferences.text: Progressive disclosure (simple by default, depth on demand)
